subject: Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... So cool! I so wish I d thought of that! ... dictionary. I ... If you are using the CMU dictionary, the entries include stress marks next to the phonetics
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:

>I have seemed to work out a way to download the top stores, convert
>these stories to Quikscript, and post them on my site.

So cool! I so wish I'd thought of that!


>That's where the real heart of this whole process lies--in the
dictionary. I
>was lucky that there is a word data base of 100 000 words, that lists
>words with suffixes and prefixes. So a portion looks like this:

If you are using the CMU dictionary, the entries include stress marks
next to the phonetics (a number 0, 1 or 2). In particular 0 means no
stress. If you felt like it, this could be used to approximate the
rules for terminal unstressed "y" "al" "el" "le" "ier" "ey "ie" etc if
desired (things explicitly needed in senior anyway). Of course such
refinements are insignificant compared with the idea and
implementation of the live-ish QS conversion in the first place.



> How is a program to know if "bush" means the shrub or the president?
In the
> future I hope the program may get a bit more sophisticated to handle
> these situations.

Not that I've tried it, but to approximate this, maybe any capital
letter not preceded but terminal punctuation (period, question mark
etc) and not starting a block of text can be assumed to be a name.
